La habitación estaba en silencio, solo se escuchaba el sonido de la lluvia que caía fuera, y el crujido de las maderas de la cama. De repente, el hombre abrió los ojos y se incorporó, mirando a su alrededor con una expresión de confusión. Luego, se levantó y se dirijió a la ventana, donde se detuvo a mirar la lluvia. Su figura se recortaba contra la luz que entraba por la ventana, y su silueta era la de un hombre que había visto muchas cosas en su vida, y que ahora se encontraba solo con sus pensamientos.

I was left standing there, feeling bereft and bewildered, wondering what had just happened.

en_second_half: was guarded by a lake that was at least a mile around, and the third side had a drainage ditch; from the map, it looked to be about as wide as a two-lane road. And where there are water-filled drainage ditches near lakes in Florida, there are often alligators.

en_results_raw: was a dense thicket of mangroves that seemed to stretch on forever, the branches tangled together in a way that made it impossible to see more than a few feet in. The third side, the one we would be approaching, was a steep, rocky cliff that dropped off into the water with no beach or shore in sight. Margo had chosen our entry point carefully, a small, narrow inlet that was partially hidden by a cluster of boulders. She had warned us that the water would be deep and the current strong, but that it was our best chance of getting in undetected. As I studied the map, I couldn't help but feel a sense of trepidation. The moat was a daunting obstacle, and the thought of navigating it in the dark, with the added risk of being caught by the night watchmen, made my stomach twist with anxiety. I glanced over at my companions, wondering if they were feeling the same sense of unease. Margo's face was set in a determined expression, her eyes fixed intently on the map. The others seemed calm, but I could sense a underlying tension in their body language. We all knew the risks, and we all knew what was at stake. We were in this together, and we would see it through, no matter what lay ahead.

en_results_raw: and I'd be wide awake again, my mind racing with thoughts of the day's events. I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off, that the world outside my window was holding its breath, waiting for something to happen. The darkness seemed to press in on me, making my skin prickle with unease. I tossed and turned, trying to find a comfortable position, but my body felt restless, like it was trying to tell me something. I threw off the covers and got out of bed, padding over to the window to stare out into the night. The stars twinkled like diamonds scattered across the sky, and the moon cast an silver glow over everything. I felt small and insignificant in the face of such vastness, yet at the same time, I felt a sense of connection to it all, like I was a part of something much bigger than myself. I stood there for a long time, lost in thought, until the first light of dawn began to creep over the horizon.

en_results_raw: it had never ended well. The teachers would just take the phones away, and the students would get in trouble. We knew that wouldn't solve anything, so we just sat there, waiting for the bell to ring, signaling the end of class. The silence was awkward, but it was better than trying to focus on the lesson when all we could think about was what was going on outside those walls. I glanced around the room, noticing the mix of emotions on my classmates' faces. Some looked worried, others seemed distracted, and a few appeared to be trying to tune it out, focusing on their notes or the teacher's words. I, on the other hand, couldn't help but feel a sense of unease, my mind wandering to all the possible scenarios that could be unfolding outside. The minutes ticked by at a glacial pace, each one feeling like an eternity. Finally, the bell rang, and the room erupted into a cacophony of chatter and shuffling papers. We all breathed a collective sigh of relief as we gathered our belongings and filed out of the classroom, eager to find out what was going on.

en_first_half: So what he did was he took a pencil and one of those steel compass things, and he started drawing circles onto a piece of paper. All the circles exactly two inches in diameter. en_second_half: kid’s problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, only the routine became destructive. But I think about the circles kid sometimes, because I can sort of understand him. I always liked routine. I suppose I never found boredom very boring. I doubted I could explain it to someone like Margo, but drawing circles through life struck me as a kind of reasonable insanity.

en_results_raw: was a cry for help, that he was trying to tell us something, but nobody knew what it was, and my dad just thought he was being lazy and not paying attention, but my mom knew better, she knew that there was something deeper going on, something that we couldn't see. And it got to the point where we had to take him to see a specialist, someone who could help him work through whatever it was that was going on in his head. And the specialist said that it was some kind of obsessive compulsive disorder, that he was using the circles as a way to cope with some kind of anxiety or stress that he was feeling. And we were all like, what anxiety, what stress, he's just a kid, what could he possibly have to be stressed about? But the specialist just said that we didn't understand, that kids can feel stress and anxiety just like adults, and that sometimes they don't know how to express it, so they find ways to cope, like drawing circles. And my mom was like, oh my god, I knew it, I knew something was wrong, and my dad was like, okay, okay, we'll get him the help he needs. And we did, we got him into therapy, and he started to open up, to talk about what was going on in his head, and it was like a weight had been lifted off of his shoulders, and he slowly started to stop drawing the circles, and started to pay attention in school, and started to be a kid again. And my mom was like, I told you, I knew something was wrong, and my dad was like, yeah, yeah, you were right. And we were all just relieved, relieved that we had gotten him the help he needed, and that he was going to be okay.

es_first_half: Lo que hizo el niño fue coger un lápiz y un compás, y empezar a dibujar circunferencias en una hoja de papel. Todas las circunferencias de exactamente cinco centímetros de diámetro. Y dibujaba circunferencias hasta que toda la hoja de papel quedaba totalmente negra. Entonces cogía otra hoja y dibujaba más circunferencias. Y lo hacía todos los días, a todas horas. No prestaba atención en clase, dibujaba circunferencias en todos los exámenes, y mi madre me dijo que el problema del niño era que había generado una rutina para sobrellevar
es_second_half: su pérdida, pero que la rutina se había vuelto destructiva. El caso es que mi madre consiguió que llorara por su padre, y el niño dejó de dibujar circunferencias y al parecer desde entonces vivió feliz. Pero de vez en cuando pienso en el niño de las circunferencias, porque de alguna manera lo entiendo. Siempre me han gustado las rutinas. Supongo que aburrirme nunca me había aburrido demasiado. Suponía que no podría explicárselo a alguien como Margo, pero pasarte la vida dibujando circunferencias me parecía una locura hasta cierto punto razonable.

Me detuve, jadeando, y miré el hueco con sorpresa. ¿Qué había pasado? ¿Qué había descubierto? Me incliné para mirar más de cerca y vi algo que me hizo saltar de sorpresa. Un pequeño objeto metálico, brillante y reluciente, asomaba en el fondo del hueco. Lo saqué con cuidado y lo examiné. Era un pequeño cofre, adornado con símbolos extraños. Me pregunté qué podría contener. ¿Un tesoro? ¿Un mensaje secreto? ¿O algo más? Mi corazón latía con emoción mientras intentaba abrir el cofre. Pero estaba cerrado con llave. Me maldije por no tener una llave. Pero no me di por vencido. Seguí buscando alrededor, con la esperanza de encontrar algo que me ayudara a abrir el cofre. Y entonces, entre las raíces del árbol, vi algo que me hizo sonreír. Una pequeña llave, escondida entre las raíces. La tomé y la introduje en la cerradura del cofre. Se abrió con un clic. Mi corazón latía con emoción mientras levantaba la tapa. Y entonces, vi algo que me hizo contener la respiración. Un papel, amarillento y viejo, con un mensaje escrito a mano. Lo leí, y mi mundo cambió para siempre.

As I continued to search the room, I found a few more clues that suggested Margo had been living here for some time, but nothing that gave me any idea where she might have gone. I was about to give up when I noticed a small, almost imperceptible line on the wall. It looked like a faint pencil mark, and it seemed to be pointing to something. I followed the line with my finger, and it led me to a small, hidden compartment in the wall. Inside, I found a note that read: "Meet me at the old oak at midnight. Come alone." It was unsigned, but I had a feeling that it was from Margo. I wondered who she was meeting, and what it might have to do with her disappearance. I decided to investigate further, and to be at the old oak at midnight, alone.

en_first_half: But I could also imagine this: Margo picking these books up at various garage sales, buying every travel guide she could get her hands on for a quarter or less. And then coming here—even before she disappeared—to read the books away from prying eyes. Reading them, trying to decide on destinations. Yes. She would stay on the road and in hiding, a balloon floating through the sky,
en_second_half: eating up hundreds of miles a day with the help of a perpetual tailwind. And in this imagining, she was alive. Had she brought me here to give me the clues to piece together an itinerary? Maybe. Of course I was nowhere near an itinerary. Judging from the books, she could be in Jamaica or Namibia, Topeka or Beijing. But I had only just begun to look.
en_results: never touching down, never staying in one place long enough to be caught. And the books, they would be her lifeline, her connection to the world she left behind. She would read about the places she wanted to visit, the people she wanted to meet, the foods she wanted to taste. She would live vicariously through the pages, imagining herself in the shoes
en_results_raw: never touching down, never staying in one place long enough to be caught. And the books, they would be her lifeline, her connection to the world she left behind. She would read about the places she wanted to visit, the people she wanted to meet, the foods she wanted to taste. She would live vicariously through the pages, imagining herself in the shoes of the travelers who wrote them. And when she finally settled on a destination, she would use the books to plan her trip, to learn the language, to know what to expect. The books would be her guide, her protector, her friend. Me explicó que había estado investigando durante semanas y que finalmente había encontrado la oportunidad perfecta para obtener pruebas. Mientras corríamos, Lacey me mostró las fotos que había tomado con su cámara, que mostraban al hombre sospechoso entrando en la casa de los vecinos. Me dijo que necesitábamos llegar allí lo antes posible para atrapar al ladrón y obtener las pruebas que necesitábamos. Corrimos lo más rápido que pudimos, nuestros corazones latiendo con emoción y adrenalina. Finalmente, llegamos a la casa de los vecinos y Lacey me hizo una señal para que me quedara quieto. Se acercó a la puerta y la abrió lentamente, mirando adentro con cuidado. De repente, escuchamos un ruido y Lacey me hizo una señal para que entrara. Entramos en la casa y nos encontramos en un cuarto oscuro y silencioso. De repente, escuchamos pasos y Lacey me dijo que era el ladrón. Nos preparamos para atraparlo, pero de repente, todo se puso negro.

en_first_half: But hadn’t I been trying to do that? I looked up at the maps above my computer. I had tried to plot her possible travels, but just as the grass stood for too much, so Margo stood for too much. It seemed impossible to pin her down with maps. She was
en_second_half: too small and the space covered by the maps too big. en_results_raw: everywhere and nowhere at the same time, a ghostly figure that haunted the edges of my perception. I rubbed my tired eyes, feeling the weight of my own exhaustion. How could I expect to track someone who seemed to defy the very fabric of space and time? And yet, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was close, that Margo was just out of reach, waiting for me to make the next move. I leaned back in my chair, my mind racing with possibilities, as I stared blankly at the maps, willing them to reveal their secrets. The silence in the room was oppressive, punctuated only by the soft hum of the computer and the creaks and groans of the old building. I was trapped in a sea of uncertainty, with no clear direction to follow. But I knew I had to keep trying, had to keep pushing forward, no matter how futile it seemed. For Margo, for myself, for the sake of uncovering the truth, I had to keep going.

es_results_raw: La luz del atardecer se reflejaba en los cristales, creando un abismo de colores que parecían bailar en el aire. Me sentí envuelto en ese momento, como si el tiempo se hubiera detenido y solo existiéramos yo y la ventana. La habitación a mi alrededor se desvaneció, y solo quedó el reflejo de la luz, recordándome momentos pasados, momentos que nunca podrían ser olvidados. La ventana se convirtió en un portal al pasado, un recordatorio de lo que habíamos vivido, de lo que habíamos sentido. Y en ese momento, supe que nunca podría dejar de mirar por esa ventana, porque era mi conexión con el pasado, mi conexión conmigo mismo.

en_results_raw: can't, because every step of the way is designed to make you feel like you're exactly where you're meant to be. I thought about all the little details she'd included, from the way the sunlight filtered through the windows to the smell of freshly baked cookies wafting from the kitchen. It was as if she'd anticipated every possible objection, every potential moment of doubt, and had carefully crafted a response to each one. And yet, despite all this, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was just going through the motions, that I was trapped in some kind of elaborate simulation, and that the real world was waiting for me just beyond the edge of perception. I felt like I was living in a dream, a dream that was so real, so vivid, that I couldn't wake up from it, no matter how hard I tried.

en_first_half: I was already up and paging through travel guides when my parents came into my room on Friday morning. They rarely both entered the
en_second_half: room at the same time, and I felt a ripple of nausea—maybe they had bad news about Margo—before I remembered it was my graduation day.
en_results: at the same time, so I knew something was up. My mom was holding a cup of coffee and my dad had a strange look on his face, a mix of excitement
en_results_raw: at the same time, so I knew something was up. My mom was holding a cup of coffee and my dad had a strange look on his face, a mix of excitement and nervousness. I immediately sensed that something was off, and my heart started racing as I wondered what was going on. "What's going on?" I asked, trying to sound calm, but my voice was shaking slightly. My mom sat down on the bed beside me, and my dad leaned against the doorframe, his eyes fixed on me. "We need to talk to you about something," he said, his voice low and serious. I felt a knot forming in my stomach as I waited for him to continue. "What is it?" I pressed, my curiosity getting the better of me. My mom took a deep breath before speaking, "We've been thinking a lot about our family vacation, and we've decided to do something different this year." I raised an eyebrow, intrigued. "What do you mean?" I asked, my mind racing with possibilities. My dad pushed off from the doorframe and walked over to the bed, sitting down beside my mom. "We're going to take a road trip," he announced, a small smile spreading across his face. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. A road trip? That wasn't our usual family vacation style. We usually went to the beach or the mountains, somewhere with a lot of activities and things to do. A road trip sounded boring, but at the same time, it sounded kind of exciting. I had never been on a road trip before, and the thought of exploring new places and seeing new things was thrilling. "Where are we going?" I asked, my excitement growing. My parents exchanged a look, and then my mom spoke up, "We're going to drive across the country, visit some of the major landmarks, and see some of the most beautiful sights in the US." I couldn't believe what I was hearing. A road trip across the country? That sounded like an adventure of a lifetime. I felt a surge of excitement and anticipation, and I couldn't wait to start our journey.

es_first_half: El viernes por la mañana estaba ya levantado, hojeando guías de viajes, cuando mis padres entraron en mi habitación. Como rara vez entraban los
es_second_half: dos juntos, me dio un vuelco el estómago —quizá tenían malas noticias de Margo—, pero de pronto recordé que era el día de mi graduación.
es_results: dos en mi habitación sin llamar, me extrañó un poco. Mi madre se acercó a mí y me dijo que tenían que hablarme de algo importante. Mi padre
es_results_raw: dos en mi habitación sin llamar, me extrañó un poco. Mi madre se acercó a mí y me dijo que tenían que hablarme de algo importante. Mi padre se sentó en la cama, a mi lado, y comenzó a explicarme que habían estado pensando en hacer un viaje familiar durante las vacaciones de verano. Me emocioné mucho al escuchar esto, ya que hacía mucho tiempo que no pasábamos unas vacaciones juntos como familia. Me preguntaron si me gustaría ir al mar o a la montaña, y comencé a soñar con las posibilidades. Mi madre me interrumpió y me dijo que había algo más que tenían que decirme, algo que podría cambiar un poco nuestros planes. Me miré a mi padre, que asintió con la cabeza, y mi madre continuó explicándome que mi abuela, que vivía en el extranjero, estaba enferma y que quizás necesitáramos allí. Me sentí un poco triste al escuchar esto, pero también sabía que teníamos que estar allí para apoyar a mi abuela en ese momento difícil. Mi padre me puso la mano en el hombro y me dijo que todo saldría bien, que siempre estábamos juntos como familia. Me sentí un poco más tranquilo, sabiendo que mi familia siempre estaría allí para mí, no importaba lo que pasara.

en_results_raw: like a failure, a defeat, a surrender. It feels like you're giving up on the people and the places you love. But Margo knows that leaving is not the opposite of staying, it's the opposite of arriving. And once you've arrived, you can't stay. You have to keep moving, keep leaving, to keep finding new places to arrive at. And that's the secret to a life of adventure, of excitement, of never-ending discovery. It's not about the places you go, it's about the person you become when you get there. And Margo knows that the person she becomes when she leaves is the person she's meant to be.

"What are you trying to say, exactly?" I ask, my voice firm but controlled. He looks at me, his eyes searching mine, and for a moment, I think I see a glimmer of understanding there. But then his face hardens, and he looks away, his jaw clenched. "I'm just saying that maybe you're not as invested in this as you think you are," he says, his voice low and even. I feel a surge of frustration, but I try to keep my cool, knowing that getting angry won't help the situation. I take another deep breath and try to think clearly, trying to understand what he's getting at. "What do you mean?" I ask, my voice still firm but curious. He looks at me again, his eyes narrowing slightly. "I mean that maybe you're just caught up in the excitement of it all," he says. "Maybe you're not really thinking about what's best for Margo, or for yourself, for that matter." I feel a sting from his words, but I try to consider them, trying to see if there's any truth to what he's saying. I think back to all the time I've spent with Margo, all the things we've been through together. And I realize that he's right - I have been caught up in the excitement of it all, the thrill of the unknown, the rush of adrenaline. But that doesn't mean I don't care about Margo, or that I'm not invested in her well-being. I care about her deeply, and I want what's best for her, no matter what that is. I look at him, my eyes locked on his. "You're right," I say, my voice firm. "I have been caught up in the excitement of it all. But that doesn't mean I don't care about Margo. I do care, deeply. And I want what's best for her, no matter what that is." He looks at me, his expression unreadable, and for a moment, I wonder if I've gotten through to him. But then he nods, slightly, and looks away, his jaw still clenched. "Good," he says. "Then let's focus on figuring out what that is." I nod, feeling a sense of relief wash over me. Maybe, just maybe, we can figure this out after all.
